speaker: Episodic Comedy (TV)
text: Bob Daily, Lori Kirkland, Dan O'Shannon  ## Nominated  AMERICAN CINEMA EDITORS AWARD (Eddie)
nextSpeaker: Best Edited Half-Hour Series For Television

speaker: Best Edited Half-Hour Series For Television
text: Ron Volk  * * *  ## Transcript {David Langley}    _ACT ONE  Scene One - Niles' Hospital Room Fade in. Niles is in the bed, Daphne is puttering around.  Niles holds up a card._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, this one's from your mom.  A kitten in a basket of yarn. [_He opens it to read._] "Dear Niles, I know we haven't always gotten along..."
prevSpeaker: Best Edited Half-Hour Series For Television

speaker: Niles
text: Wasn't that sweet of her?

speaker: Frasier
text: Hey, Niles, look what I found in the parking lot.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Niles.  It's good to see you. [_crossing to Daphne_] How's he doing?

speaker: Daphne
text: The doctor says he's doing just great.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, he looks just great. [_whispering to Daphne_] Why is he so pale?

speaker: Niles
text: [_who's heard her, whispering_] He's always this pale.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll take those.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles, you've got quite an impressive array of flowers here.  Oh, dear lord, who sent mums?

speaker: Niles
text: Those are from Jaime, [_pronounced hi-may_] our squash valet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  You know, when I had the flu, Jaime didn't send me so much as a card.

speaker: Niles
text: You didn't have the flu, you barely had the sniffles.

speaker: Frasier
text: I almost threw up.  Who knows, mums might have been just the thing to cheer me up.  I guess we'll never know now, will we?

speaker: Roz
text: I'm so sorry you have to go through all this, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I'm pretty used to him by now.

speaker: Roz
text: No, I meant...

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, right, the... umm... [_pointing at his chest_] Yes, well, thank you.  Who knew all those years of fois gras and brie would finally catch up with me.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, Frasier, you might want to get yourself checked out.  You eat a lot of that stuff too.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but I also drink a lot of red wine.  Now, Niles, you'll be happy to know that your prognosis is excellent.  I have done some research.  I have detailed the procedures and made copies for each of you.  Here we are.

speaker: Frasier
text: I also took the liberty of checking out your surgeon.  A fine choice.  True, he did have a few brushes with the law.  As an undergrad.  And I think you all know how I feel about Tulane's medical school.

speaker: Frasier
text: But, on the bright side, he has been extensively published and his reputation is stellar.  Now, if you'll all please turn to page seventeen in your handouts... you know, where is Dad?

speaker: Daphne
text: He stepped outside for some coffee.

speaker: Frasier
text: I specifically used layman's terms for his benefit.  Oh, all right.

speaker: Roz
text: How's he handling all this?

speaker: Niles
text: He's positively chirpy.  In other words, he's terrified.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, when we were kids, whenever one of us was sick or hurt, Dad would try to keep us from worrying by pretending the problem didn't even exist.

speaker: Niles
text: Nonchalance was his coping mechanism.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sitting on the edge of the bed_] Things always turned out all right, though.  It will this time, too.

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Daphne_] How are you holding up?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, you know...

speaker: Roz
text: You know what?  I think you should think of something really cool to do when all this is over.  Like a big trip.  That way you can have something good to focus on.

speaker: Daphne
text: I can't think about that right now.

speaker: Martin
text: What the hey!  Still in bed?  It's nine in the morning. Up and at 'em, lazy bones.

speaker: Ling
text: Hello, I'm your anesthesiologist, Doctor Ling.  How are you feeling today?

speaker: Niles
text: Hello.

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, don't let this faker fool you, he's just tryin' to get out of work.

speaker: Ling
text: If you're feeling at all anxious, I can give you a mild sedative.

speaker: Niles
text: No, thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you sure, Niles?  Dr. Ling went to Duke.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello?  Can I ask who's calling?  Just a minute, please.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's Maris.  Do you want me to make up an excuse?

speaker: Niles
text: No, that's okay, I'll talk to her.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello?  Well, yes, how'd you hear?  Ah, Jaime is a bit of a gossip.  Luckily they discovered the blockage before I had a major event.  Well thank you.  That wasn't the nurse, that was my wife.  Yes, Daphne.  Uh, we were married a couple months ago.  No, well, ah it's not really my fault you didn't know.  Sounds to me like your argument is with Jaime.  Well, if it makes you feel any better, we didn't invite anyone.

speaker: Niles
text: Dr. Ling?

speaker: Niles
text: [_whispers_] Give me the drugs. _She turns to the IV setup and prepares the sedative.  Niles puts the phone back to his ear._

speaker: Niles
text: Uh-huh.  Uh-huh.  Well yes, of course we invited him, he's my brother.  Uh, yes, William Sonoma and Tiffany's. [_to Dr. Ling_] Keep it coming. _As she injects his IV line, Niles goes back to the phone.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Niles' Hospital Room Fade in. Daphne and Dr. Ling are at the bedside, the others are sitting down._

speaker: Ling
text: Now in just a few moments, we'll be ready to wheel you down to the OR.

speaker: Frasier
text: He'll receive general anesthesia once he's on the operating table.  Now, if you'd like to follow along in your handouts, I could take you through the first steps of the procedure.

speaker: Daphne
text: The doctor explained everything to us yesterday.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but did he have a mnemonic verse that goes along to the tune of "Camp Town Races"?

speaker: Schafer
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_getting up_] Ah, Doctor Schafer.  I was just explaining my brother's procedure to my family.  I'll hand the floor over to you.

speaker: Schafer
text: Thank you...

speaker: Frasier
text: Frasier.  Dr. Crane.

speaker: Schafer
text: Oh, great. [_to Niles_] Once you're under, we'll begin by inserting some tubes to monitor your blood pressure. Then, while one team harvests the saphenous vein from your right leg, I'll be opening up your chest.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me.  If I may, wouldn't a mid-cab be less invasive? I have done some research in the matter and I believe that is the prevailing methodology.

speaker: Schafer
text: Well, you may have read about that in Reader's Digest, but a mid-cab is only appropriate for a limited blockage.

speaker: Frasier
text: My source is not Reader's Digest.  It is a Harvard colleague. Harvard being my alma mater.  HARVARD.  And if I'm not mistaken, the blockage is in the left anterior descending artery.

speaker: Schafer
text: And the right coronary.  Look, in my expert opinion, I'm doing what's best for this patient.

speaker: Frasier
text: And my expert opinion says otherwise.

speaker: Schafer
text: Well, if you're such an expert, maybe you should perform the surgery.

speaker: Frasier
text: Maybe I should!

speaker: Niles
text: Dad...

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, you're not operating on your brother.

speaker: Frasier
text: Suit yourself.

speaker: Ling
text: Maybe it would be best if everyone stepped out while Dr. Schafer talks to the patient.

speaker: Schafer
text: Mrs. Crane, you're welcome to stay.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I'll, I'll see you before they wheel you in. _He, Martin and Roz step outside.  Reset to: the hallway as they come out._

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'll tell you one thing about that Dr. Schafer's people skills: I am not a fan.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, will you leave it alone?  You're being a big pain.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I happen to know a thing or...

speaker: Frasier
text: A thing or two about bypass surgery, he was totally condescending to me.

speaker: Martin
text: He was just trying to let you know who's in charge.  I'm sure at the first sign of trouble, he'll run right out here to consult with you.

speaker: Roz
text: This is so weird.  I mean, twenty-four hours ago, we didn't even know anything was wrong with Niles.  It just goes to show, you can't take a second for granted.

speaker: Martin
text: You sure can't.  You can't take people for granted, either. You just never know.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's true.  That's why you should always tell the people you love just how much they mean to you.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I hope you guys know how much I care about you.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez, sure we do.  And we care about you, too.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course, Roz, you're like family.  And Dad, I hope you know I love you.  Even at your most difficult.

speaker: Martin
text: Well I love you too, Son, even when you treat me like a child.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier bosses everyone around.  It's just his way.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps if people behaved more competently, I wouldn't be so bossy.

speaker: Martin
text: Maybe you wouldn't be so bossy if you didn't always focus on how everybody else behaves.

speaker: Roz
text: That'd be the day.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, maybe that's because human behavior is my profession.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you can take a day off once in a while.

speaker: Roz
text: No kidding.

speaker: Frasier
text: Who asked you, Roz?

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles is going off to surgery soon.  Come and wish him well.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, we really should tell her how much she means to us, too. _They head back in.  Reset to: the hospital room. Daphne is sitting down on the bed.  The others pause in the doorway._

speaker: Daphne
text: How you feeling?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm a little woozy.  Maybe I should lie down.  Oh, now Daphne, you know all the important papers are in my top left hand drawer...

speaker: Daphne
text: Let's not talk about that right now.  You just relax.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, Daphne.  You know, Daphne, they do these procedures hundreds of times.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay.  It's practically routine, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Why do you keep saying my name?

speaker: Niles
text: I just want to say it as many times as I can... Daphne.

speaker: Martin
text: What?  Still in bed?  Will you look at this goldbrick?  Well, if you're gonna be loafin' around all day, you might as well have somethin' to read.  I know how you love your Archies.

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks, Dad.  Oh, a Jughead Double Digest.

speaker: Martin
text: I'll be here waiting for you.  I love you, Son.

speaker: Niles
text: I love you, too.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I have a confession to make.  Remember when we were kids and I was wearing your opera cape and you pushed me down the stairs?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: You didn't push me.  I jumped.  I was trying to fly like a Valkyrie.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not important right now.  It's important you get well, all right? _ A nurse and an orderly come in with a gurney. _

speaker: Orderly
text: Dr. Crane?  Mrs. Crane?  It's that time.  Okay, we're gonna need you to slide over.

speaker: Niles
text: Boy, a hospital is an interesting place, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: How so, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, all roads lead to the hospital.  We're born here, we get sick here, we get well here.  All these big dramatic moments and the hospital just gobbles 'em up.  Do you think a hospital has memories?  I bet it does.  I bet when I walked in it thought "Oh, you again.  You're the little boy who broke his leg in 1966.  Hello, old friend."  Wow, a talking hospital. That would be cool.  When are these drugs going to kick in? I don't even know why I need surgery.  This is the best I've felt in years.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, Daphne, Daphne, Daphne, Daphne, Daphne...

speaker: Orderly
text: Okay, you ready to take a little trip?

speaker: Frasier
text: I think he already is.

speaker: Daphne
text: Can I just have a second?

speaker: Orderly
text: Of course.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll be here when you wake up.

speaker: Niles
text: Promise?

speaker: Daphne
text: I promise. _She kisses him and they wheel the gurney out the door.  Reset to: a shot looking down at Niles as he's rolled downed the hallway.  The shot then goes to point of view from behind the orderly as they pass the rooms in the hallway.  He passes a room and we see a young Niles, his foot in a cast and raised.  A young Frasier and a young Martin (with a mustache) stand by his bed._

speaker: Martin
text: What do you mean, you don't like Archie?  It's a riot.  You got your Jughead, your Reggie, your Mr. Weatherby... _The shot pulls over to a room on the other side where we see an Adult Niles sitting at the bedside of a woman whose face is covered by bandages._

speaker: Niles
text: Please stop crying, Maris.  The doctor can always cut off more next time. _The shot pans over to another door.  A doctor hands the orderly a clipboard and he signs.  Through the doorway we see Daphne leaning over Niles._

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll be here when you wake up.

speaker: Niles
text: Promise?

speaker: Daphne
text: Promise. _The orderly pushes the gurney through a set of doors to the operating areas.  FADE OUT  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_ **THE WAITING IS THE HARDEST PART** _Scene One - The Waiting Room Fade in. Roz and Daphne are sitting down, Martin and Frasier are standing at a magazine rack._

speaker: Martin
text: [_thumbing through a magazine_] How come these places never have any magazines for men?  It's all hairdos and recipes and butt exercises.

speaker: Frasier
text: I was just thinking about what Niles said about the hospital and the things that happen here.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez, would you look at this: "Ten Saucy Secrets to Please Him in Bed."  You know damn well there are only four.  The rest are just do-si-dos.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's like the whole tapestry of life keeps replaying itself in these four walls.

speaker: Martin
text: [_still reading_] I used to bust people for that one.

speaker: Frasier
text: You didn't hear a word I said, did you?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I did.  Hospital, tapestry of life... [_covering_] Whoa!  Nice kitchen.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're a sentimental fool, Dad. _He follows.  As he passes the door, we see Martin holding a toddler Frasier up to a hospital basinet.  In front of them, Hester, face hidden by the doorjamb, is sitting up in bed._

speaker: Martin
text: Well, here he is.  Frasier, say hello to your new brother.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't like him.

speaker: Martin
text: Remember when you were little and you convinced Niles that we were all figments of his imagination and the whole world was just in is mind?

speaker: Frasier
text: I told him we disappeared whenever he left the room.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, for months afterwards he was always darting into rooms to make sure we were still there.  Scared the crap out of me, I was ready to kill you.

speaker: Frasier
text: What made you think of that?

speaker: Martin
text: I don't know, I'm just thinking about Niles.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well he must be all right, we're all still here.

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't think I've ever been this frightened in my whole life.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_grabbing his folder_] Well, Daph, according to my timetable, Niles is probably off the bypass pump by now, all the blockages have been bypassed, and the myocardium is now receiving normal blood.

speaker: Martin
text: How can you know all this but you're stumped by an electric barbecue fork?

speaker: Frasier
text: Because the human heart was not designed by some idiot in Japan.

speaker: Roz
text: You know, Frasier, maybe now is not the perfect time to go into detail.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's all right, Roz.

speaker: Frasier
text: You see, she knows.  Knowledge is our ally against anxiety. Which happens to be the theme of today's "Best of Crane" which is being broadcast over the airwaves right this moment.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh yeah, they're piping it into the operating room instead of using anesthesia.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very funny, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I hope the doctors have their earplugs in so they don't fall asleep too.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, we get it.

speaker: Roz
text: Seriously, if I was ever gonna rob a bank and wanted to knock out the guards...

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Roz. _They all laugh for a moment, then quiet to their thoughts again. Martin looks over at the vending machine._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, is that a Chunky in there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Looks like one.

speaker: Martin
text: Been a long time since I've seen one of those.  What are they asking for it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Looks like it's eighty-five cents.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.  Does it only take the exact change?

speaker: Frasier
text: Looks like there's a dollar slot.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, all I have is a ten.  Will it take a ten?

speaker: Frasier
text: Why don't you get off your ass and look?

speaker: Roz
text: They usually just take singles.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.  Anybody have a single?

speaker: Frasier
text: How can you think about eating now?

speaker: Martin
text: What would you rather have me think about?

speaker: Roz
text: I'll get you some change.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, thanks, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Sittin' way too long, anyway.

speaker: Roz
text: Excuse me... [_reading her name tag_] Colleen?  Do you have any ones?

speaker: Colleen
text: I think so, let me check.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks. _A flashback of Roz and Colleen comes up behind them, Roz rushing in with Alice in her arms._

speaker: Roz
text: Excuse me.

speaker: Colleen
text: Can I help you?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.  There's something wrong with my baby.  She has a little rash on her cheek.  I looked in the book, and I don't think it's chicken pox.  But it does look a little like scarlet fever.

speaker: Colleen
text: Is this your first child?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes, why?

speaker: Colleen
text: I think this is lipstick.

speaker: Colleen
text: Will fives do?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I'm afraid I need ones.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, thank God.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, look at that.  That's probably how it happened.  Thank you... [_reading her name tag_] Colleen.  I won't forget you.

speaker: Colleen
text: I'm sorry.  All I've got are fives.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, thanks anyway.

speaker: Colleen
text: Do I know you?

speaker: Roz
text: I don't think so.

speaker: Colleen
text: Are you sure?

speaker: Roz
text: Trust me.  I'm really good with faces. _She walks off.  In the waiting area, a surgical nurse comes up in scrubs._

speaker: Nurse
text: Mrs. Crane?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes.

speaker: Nurse
text: Your husband's doing well.  He's off the pump and his heart is beating on its own.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_rising_] How's his blood pressure?

speaker: Nurse
text: One hundred over sixty.

speaker: Frasier
text: Could be better.  Did you thoroughly suction the cardioplegic solution?  See, I'm a doctor.

speaker: Nurse
text: Oh, yes, Dr. Schafer told me about you.  He said if you started asking me questions, I should do this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I get it!  Very nice!

speaker: Roz
text: Well, that's good news, right?

speaker: Roz
text: They didn't have any change.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, shoot.

speaker: Martin
text: What ya reading, Daph?

speaker: Daphne
text: I have no idea.  I must have read the same paragraph ten times.  I don't know how you're getting through this.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it's not like the old days when heart surgery was a big thing.  Nowadays they do it so much it's like goin' in for a hair cut.  Read the paper and wait 'til he's done.

speaker: Daphne
text: But aren't you scared?

speaker: Martin
text: I wonder if that guy has a dollar. [_rising_] I bet he does. Excuse me. _He goes off.  After a moment Daphne puts her magazine down and grabs at her purse._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, no!

speaker: Frasier
text: What, Daph?

speaker: Daphne
text: [_rising_] I don't believe this.  Excuse me.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Daphne
text: I was supposed to bring Niles' cell phone, in case any of his patients call so I can refer them to Doctor Wells.  Now I'm going to be calling his stupid cell phone every two minutes to check his mailbox.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, here, let's use my cell phone, all right?  We can take turns calling.

speaker: Daphne
text: He asked me to do this one simple thing and I forgot. I'm such an idiot.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now don't go beating yourself up.  You didn't do anything wrong.  Come on, I'll dial first. _He starts to call.  Behind them, through the door of a room, we see a young Niles with a broken leg, Frasier talking to him._

speaker: Frasier
text: Now look, Niles, as far as Dad knows, I had nothing to do with your leg breaking, right?

speaker: Niles
text: You pushed me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and in exchange for your silence, you'll get ten of my records.  Any ones you want.

speaker: Niles
text: Even the Shostakovich?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not that one!

speaker: Niles
text: Then forget it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Sign here and initial here.

speaker: Martin
text: You still in bed, Mr. Lazybones?  Well, if you're going to lie around all day, I've got you something to read.

speaker: Niles
text: _The Charterhouse of Parma_?

speaker: Martin
text: Better: Archie! _He hands the comic over to an unimpressed Niles.  Outside, we see the current Frasier getting a drink from the water fountain as Martin comes by._

speaker: Martin
text: Well, hello Chunky!

speaker: Frasier
text: I beg your pardon?

speaker: Martin
text: I got some change.

speaker: Frasier
text: Congratulations. _Martin puts the coins into the vending machine.  He's about to press the buttons when he notices something._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, is that a Marathon Bar?  Oh, geez, now I don't know what to get.

speaker: Frasier
text: You should go with your first instinct, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: But I haven't had a Marathon Bar in years.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, then get a Marathon Bar.

speaker: Martin
text: Come to think of it, I think they quit making Marathon Bars back in the '80s.

speaker: Frasier
text: Then you should get a Chunky.

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, although, I kinda want to get a Marathon Bar just to see what it looks like on the inside.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, just get the Chunky!

speaker: Martin
text: All right.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey!

speaker: Frasier
text: What?

speaker: Martin
text: It's stuck!  Great!  You had to have Chunky!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right, I'll get it.

speaker: Roz
text: What is going on?!

speaker: Martin
text: We have a stuck Chunky.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, why did Chunky stick his arm in there?

speaker: Frasier
text: Not me, the candy!  I give up.

speaker: Roz
text: Don't worry Martin.  I'll stop by tomorrow and get us some Godiva.

speaker: Martin
text: But I want my Chunky!

speaker: Daphne
text: Excuse me. _Frasier moves aside and Daphne smashes in the glass front of the vending machine.  Colleen at the nurse's station grabs the phone. Daphne reaches into the machine and pulls out a candy bar._

speaker: Daphne
text: Chunky, was it? _She hands it to a stunned Martin and walks back to the couch, bursting into tears.  Roz rushes to embrace her._

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, Daphne, it's okay, it's okay.  Everything's gonna be fine.

speaker: Orderly
text: Do I need to call security here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, no, it's all right.  I'm sorry about this, kind of a tough time.

speaker: Orderly
text: All right, but keep this area clear until I can get it cleaned up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  And we'll pay for this.

speaker: Martin
text: [_holding up the Chunky_] And I already paid for this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, I know you're in hell right now, but in just about twenty minutes comes the disconnecting of the ventilator and the extubation.  You can see it all in the diagram on page 24-C...

speaker: Daphne
text: He's not a diagram!  He's my husband and he's lying on an operating table with his chest cut open!  I'm sorry if I can't handle this as well as the rest of you, but I'm terrified!

speaker: Roz
text: Daphne, it's okay.  Just calm down.  You know when this is all over we're...

speaker: Daphne
text: There IS no "when this is over"!  There's no tomorrow, no next week, no next year!  There's nothing until he comes out of there and I know he's okay!

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne...

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't you sit down, Son?

speaker: Martin
text: Nobody meant anything.  It's hard as hell for all of us to be here.

speaker: Daphne
text: I know.  It's just... I hate hospitals.  I hate them.  I hate all of this.

speaker: Martin
text: I know.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'm afraid your wife's x-rays don't look good. _We pull back to the present as Daphne and Martin sit back down with the others._

speaker: Roz
text: Waiting is the hardest part. _FADE TO:  Scene Two - The Recovery Room Fade in. Niles is in bed, unconscious.  A nurse is checking his vitals.  Daphne leans over him._

speaker: Daphne
text: Niles?  You did great.  The doctor said it went even better than he expected.  I am so proud of you.

speaker: Nurse
text: He'll be out all night.  Why don't you get something to eat?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'll be here when you wake up. _She kisses him on the forehead and leaves.  Reset to: the hallway as she comes out. She closes the door and walks down the hallway.  She takes some tissue from her purse and wipes her eyes.  As she passes an open doorway, we see her in a hospital bed, holding a baby.  Niles is standing over her, holding another child._

speaker: Niles
text: Say hello to your new sister.

speaker: Daphne
text: Look, she's smiling at you. _The shot turns to see Daphne walking away.  FADE OUT  END OF ACT TWO_
